revision.text:
'''Abstinence''' or the '''rule of abstinence''' is the principle of [[Psychoanalysis|analytic]] reticence and/or frustration within a clinical situation. It is a central feature of [[psychoanalytic theory]] – relating especially to the handling of the [[transference]] in analysis. As [[Freud]] wrote in 1914,Quoted in P. Gay, ''Freud'' (1989) p. 302-3
The cure must be carried through in abstinence. I mean by that not physical self-denial alone, nor the denial of every desire....But I want to state the principle that one must permit neediness and yearning to remain as forces favoring work and change.
==Later formulations== The validity of the abstinence principle has been rediscovered and re-affirmed in a variety of subsequent analytic traditions. * [[Jacques Lacan]] re-formulated the principle via the concept of 'analytic [[Contract bridge|bridge]]' – the analyst necessarily playing the part of the unresponding dummy to bring the patient's unconscious motivations out into the open.Jacques Lacan, ''Ecrits'' (1997) p. 229-30 * [[Eric Berne]] saw analytic frustration as a means of avoiding playing a part in the patient's [[Script analysis|life script]].Eric Berne, ''What Do You Say After You Say Hello?'' (1974) p. 352 * [[R. D. Laing]], in the context of the [[false self]] saw analytic abstinence operating in opposition to false self collusion: "It is in terms of basic frustration of the self's search for a collusive complement for false identity that Freud's dictum that analysis should be conducted under conditions of maximal frustration takes on its most cogent meaning".R. D. Laing, ''Self and Others'' (1969) p. 123 * [[D. W. Winnicott]] in the context of his notion of 'holding' the patient emphasised that understanding through verbal interpretation gave a deeper sense of holding than the physical act, use of which by the therapist could blur the symbolic nature of the analytic space.P. Casement, ''Further Learning from the Patient'' (1990) p. 96-7 ==Debates== The rule of abstinence has come under increasing challenge by [[Interpersonal psychoanalysis|Interpersonal]] and [[Intersubjective psychoanalysis]],A. Fayek, ''The Crisis in Psychoanalysis'' (2009) p. 37 concerned about the inflexibility of the rule, and the way its relentless application may provoke unnecessary hostility, even an [[iatrogenesis|iatrogenic]] [[transference neurosis]].R. Stolorow et al eds., ''The Intersubjective Perspective'' (1994) p. xi and p. 146 Defenders of the rule, against the practice of the warm supportive analyst, argue against the easy seductiveness of being overly 'helpful' in a self-defeating way already sketched out by Freud himself.Janet Malcolm, ''Psychoanalysis: The Impossible Profession'' (1988) p. 124 and p. 77 The concept of optimal responsiveness – balancing frustration and gratification from moment to moment – offers some mediation in the dispute.S. Akhtar, ''Comprehensive Dictionary of Psychoanalysis'' (2009) A and O ==See also== {{Columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Acting in]] * [[Acting out]] * [[Charles Rycroft]] * [[Countertransference]] * [[Evenly-suspended attention]] * [[Jean Laplanche]] * [[Parallel process]] * [[Ralph Greenson]] * [[Sándor Ferenczi]] }} ==References== {{Reflist|2|}} ==Further reading== * S. Freud, 'Observations on Transference Love' ''Standard Edition'' XII * J. Lindon, 'Gratification and provision in psychoanalysis: Should we get rid of 'the rule of abstinence'?' ''Psychoanal. Dialogues'' (1994) 4:549-582 ==External links== * [http://fox.klte.hu/~keresofi/psyth/a-to-z-entries/abstinence_.html Abstinence] * [http://www.blackwellreference.com/public/tocnode?id=g9780631170488_chunk_g97806311704884_ss1-3 Abstinence, rule of] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Clinical psychology]] [[Category:Psychoanalysis]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=April 2016}}
{{Infobox organization | image =[[File:BANlogo.jpg|BANlogo]] | name = Burn Advocates Network | type = Non-governmental organization | founded_date = 2008 | founder = Samuel Davis | location = [[New Jersey]], [[United States]] | area_served = 6 countries | mission = support burn survivors as they face the challenges of recovery, rehabilitation, and reintegration | homepage = [http://www.burnadvocates.org burnadvocates.org] }}
'''Burn Advocates Network''' (BAN) is a [[Non-profit organisation|non-profit organization]] that supports [[burn]] survivors as they face the challenges of recovery, rehabilitation, and reintegration. The organization operates 3 pediatric burn camps and a burn care network.<ref>[http://burnadvocates.org/our-mission/ Our Mission], Burn Advocates Network</ref> BAN was founded in 2008 and expanded its international activity following the [[Haiti earthquake 2010|Haiti earthquake]], which left an estimated 1,000 burn survivors without proper care.<ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/259697519_Disasters_the_2010_Haitian_earthquake_and_the_evacuation_of_burn_victims_to_US_burn_centers Disasters; the 2010 Haitian earthquake and the evacuation of burn victims to US burn centers.] Randy D. Kearnsa, James. H. Holmes IV.b, Mary Beth Skarotec, Charles B. Cairnsd, Samantha Cooksey Stricklande, Howard G. Smithf, Bruce A. Cairnsg. Burns, Volume 40, Issue 6, September 2014, Pages 1121–1132</ref>
==Operations==
Based in [[Teaneck, New Jersey|Teaneck New Jersey]], Burn Advocates Network operates 3 pediatric burn camps:
* '''Camp Sababa''' - Israel’s first burn camp, was founded in 2009 and operates in cooperation with Schneider Hospital for Children. Camp takes place in [[Kfar Galim]], a youth village outside of [[Haifa]].<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/science/1.588236 At an Israeli Children's Camp, Burn Survivors Find Relief.] Haaretz, Alona Ferber, May 01, 2014.</ref><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HMwcji7ZMDU Heal the Scars of the Heart.] Channel 10 News, Miki Haimovich, broadcast date: May 3, 2011. YouTube title: Camp Sababa - Israel's Channel 10 News Story (with subtitles)</ref> * '''Camp Karma''' - India's first burn camp, was founded in 2013 and operates in cooperation [[KEM Hospital]]. Camp takes place in Rivergate Resort, outside of [[Mumbai]].<ref>[https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2013/10/23/indias-first-burns-camp-for-kids/ India’s First Burns Camp for Kids.] The Wall Street Journal, Shreya Shah, Oct 23, 2013.</ref> *'''Camp Samba''' - Set to launch in São Paulo during summer 2016.<ref>[http://burnadvocates.org/where-we-work/brazil-camp-samba/ Where We Work], Burn Advocates Network</ref>
Today there are approximately 60 burn camps worldwide,<ref>[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20644489 Summer camps for children with burn injuries: a literature review]. Maslow GR, Lobato D. Journal of Burn Care & Research: September/October 2010 - Volume 31 - Issue 5 - pp 740-749</ref> 31 of them based in the USA and registered at the International Association of Burn Camps.<ref>[http://www.iaburncamps.org/our-story/ Our Story], The International Association of Burn Camps (IABC)</ref> Burn camps typically include accommodation, offer various activities such as arts and crafts, cooking sessions and drumming circles, and are tuition-free for campers. The age of participants varies from 6-18 and the number of participants from 15-100.<ref>[http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/nation/story/2012-08-23/burn-survivors-summer-camp/57317326/1 Burn-survivor summer camps let kids shake off the stares]. USA Today, Natalie DiBlasio, August 28, 2012.</ref> Several academic studies<ref>[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17351455 Impact of a pediatric residential burn camp experience on burn survivors' perceptions of self and attitudes regarding the camp community.] Rimmer RB, Fornaciari GM, Foster KN, Bay CR, Wadsworth MM, Wood M, Caruso DM. J Burn Care Res. 2007 Mar-Apr;28(2):334-41.</ref><ref>[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21752547 Impact of pediatric burn camps on participants' self esteem and body image: an empirical study.] Bakker A, Van der Heijden PG, Van Son MJ, Van de Schoot R, Van Loey NE. Burns. 2011 Dec;37(8):1317-25.</ref><ref>[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22210080 Burn-injured adolescents report gaining multiple developmental benefits and improved life skills as a result of burn camp attendance.] Rimmer RB, Pressman MS, Takach OP, Bay RC, Croteau R, Hansen LD, Foster KN, Caruso DM. J Burn Care Res. 2012 Jul-Aug;33(4):552-60.</ref> have demonstrated that burn survivors who participated in burn camps experienced decreased isolation, improved self-esteem and improved social skills.
BAN also initiated the '''DR & Haiti Burn Care Network''', which seeks to improve burn care and treatment in the region. Since 2010, BAN has treated over 200 burn survivors through 6 medical missions, distributed over 50,000 tons of medical supplies and equipment, and sponsored several surgeons on medical exchange programs.<ref>[http://www.northjersey.com/news/badly-needed-burn-center-in-works-1.874998?page=all Teaneck lawyer in quest to prevent burns in Haiti.] NorthJersey.com, Deena Yellin, September 17, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://jewishstandard.timesofisrael.com/local-lawyer-expands-burn-network-to-haiti/ Local lawyer expands burn network to Haiti.] Jewish Standard, Abigail Klein Leichman, June 25, 2010.</ref> In order to improve communication between aid workers and local victims, BAN launched the [[iOS app]] "French Creole for Aid Workers" in 2011.<ref>[https://www.devex.com/news/iphone-app-helps-boost-haitian-recovery-efforts-72198 IPhone App Helps Boost Haitian Recovery Efforts.] Devex, Ma. Rizza Leonzon, January 19, 2011.</ref>
==History== [[File:BAN18.jpg|thumb|Medical mission, Haiti 2011]]Founder Samuel Davis, trial lawyer and lecturer, has worked with burn survivors with serious injuries for over 30 years. After witnessing the positive effects of burn camps on his clients, he began sponsoring individual burn survivors from around the world.<ref>[http://www.bergen.com/health-and-beauty/health/helping-hands-tenafly-s-sam-davis-advocates-for-burn-victims-1.796676 Helping Hands: Tenafly's Sam Davis advocates for burn victims.] Bergen.com, February 20, 2013.</ref> The local operation quickly expanded into an international organization, following the Haiti earthquake. In 2012, Samuel Davis received the [[Clarence Darrow]] Award for his ongoing philanthropic work.<ref>[http://teaneck.dailyvoice.com/neighbors/teaneck-rotary-honors-attorney-with-humanitarian-award/607317/ Teaneck Rotary Honors Attorney With Humanitarian Award]. Teaneck Daily Voice, Melissa Heule, December 02, 2015.</ref>
==Funding==
The organization is funded through private donations and fundraising events. By relying on volunteers and interns, BAN is able to keep its camps free for all participants.<ref>[http://burnadvocates.org/financials/ Financials], Burn Advocates Network</ref> [[File:BAN20.JPG|thumb|Camp Karma, India 2013]]
==References== {{reflist}}
* * * *
[[Category:Health charities in the United States]] [[Category:Burns]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in New Jersey]]

{{Use American English|date=July 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Multiple issues| {{overly detailed|date=July 2018}} {{third-party|date=July 2018}} {{undue weight|date=July 2018}} }} {{Infobox institute | name = Chaplin Hall at the University of Chicago | image = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | latin_name = | motto = | founder = | established = | mission = | focus = [[Child and family services]] | president = | chairman = | head_label = Executive director | head = Brian Samuels | faculty = | adjunct_faculty = | staff = | key_people = | budget = | endowment = | debt = | num_members = | subsidiaries = | owner = | non-profit_slogan = | former_name = | location = University of Chicago | city = Chicago | state = Illinois | country = United States | coor = | address = | website = {{Official website|https://www.uchicago.edu/research/center/chapin_hall/|www.uchicago.edu/research/center/chapin_hall/}} | footnotes = | type = }} '''Chapin Hall at the [[University of Chicago]]''' is a [[policy research institution]] at the University of Chicago that focuses on child welfare and family well-being.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.uchicago.edu/research/center/chapin_hall/|title=Chapin Hall|website=The University of Chicago|language=en|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref> Chapin Hall is funded through social service systems,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dcs.az.gov/news/chapin-hall-report|title=Chapin Hall Report {{!}} Arizona Department of Child Safety|website=dcs.az.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref> foundations,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.wallacefoundation.org/knowledge-center/pages/about-us-chapin-hall-center-for-children-new-on-the-shelf.aspx|title=About Us: Chapin Hall Center for Children – Teens in the Library|access-date=2018-07-13|language=en-US}}</ref> and non-profit organizations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youth-guidance.org/bam/|title=BAM – Becoming A Man® – Youth Guidance|website=www.youth-guidance.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref> The organization's focus areas include child welfare and [[foster care]] systems, youth homelessness,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://voicesofyouthcount.org/chapin-hall/|title=Chapin Hall – Voices of Youth Count|website=voicesofyouthcount.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref> and community capacity to support children, youth, and families (including early childhood initiatives, home visitation and maltreatment prevention, juvenile justice, and school systems).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=100148699|title=Company Overview of Chapin Hall Center For Children|last=|first=|date=|website=Bloomburg|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref> Chapin Hall is an affiliated research center of the [[University of Chicago]].<ref name=":0" />
== History == Chapin Hall at the University of Chicago was founded in 1860 as the Chicago Nursery and Half-Orphan Asylum. In addition to housing orphans and other dependent children, the Asylum provided day care services for working mothers.
In 1931, the Chicago Nursery and Half-Orphan Asylum moved into a building at 2800 West Foster Avenue. After the move, the organization became known by the name of that building, Chapin Hall Center for Children.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://chsmedia.org/media/fa/fa/M-C/ChapinHall-inv.htm|title=Chicago Nursery and Half-Orphan Asylum. Chapin Hall for Children records, 1867–1984|last=Whalen|first=Jack|date=2013|website=Chicago History Museum|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref>
By the 1960s and 70s, Chapin Hall Center for Children was financially dependent on state money. During the 70s and 80s, national public policy shifted to fund institutional care for only "severely disturbed children." As a result of dwindling support, in 1984, Chapin Hall Center for Children decided to close its residential care program.
The following year, Chapin Hall Center for Children was re-opened as a policy research center affiliated with the University of Chicago. The goal of the newly formed organization was to conduct research about child welfare and well-being, in alignment with its history as a residential care facility. [[Harold Richman|Harold A. Richman]] was the first executive director of the research center and held that role through 2008.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=A Home of Another Kind: One Chicago Orphanage and the Tangle of Child Welfare|last=Cmiel|first=Kenneth|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=1995|isbn=0-226-11084-2|location=Chicago|pages=1–3, 184–186}}</ref>
== Research and policy initiatives == Chapin Hall's three major areas of focus are child welfare, community capacity building, and [[youth homelessness]]. [9] Chapin Hall houses a number of ongoing initiatives related to child, youth, and family well-being.
=== Center for State Child Welfare Data === The Center for State Child Welfare Data is a platform that enables [[public sector]] agencies to store and analyze administrative data related to children placed in [[out-of-home care]]. {{As of|2017}}, 22 states used the platform, covering about 70% of children in the U.S. in the child welfare system.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}}
One component of Center is the Foster Care Data Archive. The archive provides access to information about children in the foster care system over time.
In addition to providing a platform for the data, Chapin Hall staff help members [[analyze data]] for both policymaking and in practice.<ref>Center for Substance Abuse Treatment. Introduction to Cross-System Data Sources in Child Welfare, Alcohol and Other Drug Services, and Courts. HHS Publication No. (SMA) 11-4630. Rockville, MD: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, 2011. pp 14-15.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://fcda.chapinhall.org/|title=Center for State Child Welfare Data {{!}} Continuous Quality Improvement|website=The Center for State Child Welfare Data|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/data-labs/the-center-for-state-child-welfare-data-fbe64f1b743|title=The Center for State Child Welfare Data|last=GovLab|first=The|date=2017-12-12|website=Data Labs|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref>
=== Doris Duke Fellowship for the Promotion of Child Well-Being === Chapin Hall receives financial support from the [[Doris Duke Charitable Foundation]] to run a fellowship program for current and recent graduate students interested in child well-being and maltreatment prevention.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.dorisdukefellowships.org/about/|title=About|website=Doris Duke Fellowships|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref>
Researchers in the program are from multiple disciplines including social work, child development, public health, medicine, public policy, education, economics, psychology, and epidemiology. Fellows receive thirty thousand dollars to complete their dissertation and related research.<ref name=":2" />
=== Transformational Collaborative Outcomes Management === Transformational Collaborative Outcomes Management (TCOM) is a framework for decision-making in complex systems. TCOM provides tools and guidance on an individual, program, and system level to help support decisions, monitor outcomes, and improve quality in child welfare systems.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://praedfoundation.org/tools/transformational-collaborative-outcomes-management-tcom/|title=Transformational Collaborative Outcomes Management (TCOM) {{!}} Praed Foundation|website=praedfoundation.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref>
TCOM is the foundation of Child and Adolescent Needs and Strengths (CANS), an assessment strategy for monitoring the well-being of children and youth. CANS is broadly used in child welfare. As of 2018, the CANS was being used by nearly 5,000 agencies across 10 countries, including all 50 U.S. states. The assessment is used in the fields of child welfare, mental health, juvenile justice, autism and developmental health, and early intervention.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lyons|first=John|date=March 23, 2014|title=Use of the Child and Adolescent Needs and Strengths (CANS) in Child Welfare in the United States|url=http://www.ohiochildrensalliance.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/CANS-in-child-welfare-report.pdf|journal=Ohio Association of Child Caring Agencies, Inc|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://praedfoundation.org/tools/the-child-and-adolescent-needs-and-strengths-cans/|title=The Child and Adolescent Needs and Strengths (CANS) {{!}} Praed Foundation|website=praedfoundation.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref>
The CANS-MH is a variant of the CANS for children and adolescents with mental health challenges. The tool has been shown to be a "reliable measure of psychosocial needs and strengths".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Anderson|first=Rachel L.|date=2003|title=Reliability of the Child and Adolescent Needs and Strengths-Mental Health (CANS-MH) Scale|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023/A:1023935726541|journal=Journal of Child and Family Studies|language=en|volume=12|issue=3|pages=279–289|doi=10.1023/a:1023935726541|issn=1062-1024}}</ref>
=== Oak Park Collaboration for Early Childhood === The Collaboration for Early Childhood is a nonprofit organization in [[Oak Park, Illinois]] that works to connect parents of young children to local resources. Their website also houses resource directories for health care professionals, educators, and service providers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://collab4kids.org/|title=Collaboration for Early Childhood: Strong Start, Bright Future|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref>
Starting in 2013, the Collaboration for Early Childhood entered a five-year contract with Chapin Hall to build a comprehensive early childhood database. The database will unify administrative data sources, providing users with a view of school enrollment and poverty at a local level in Oak Park. Information on subsidized child care and [[Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program|SNAP]] benefits will be available at a state level. Once the database is live, providers will be able to access and analyze these data to help inform program and practice decision-making.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://collab4kids.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Collaboration_IGA_Exec_Summ_May2015.pdf|title=Executive Summary|last=|first=|date=May 2015|website=Collaboration for Early Childhood|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oakpark.com/News/Articles/5-12-2015/Oak-Park-area-could-be-state-model--for-early-childhood-data/|title=Oak Park area could be state model for early childhood data|website=www.oakpark.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref>
=== Voices of Youth Count Initiative === Voices of Youth Count is a research initiative on youth experiences of [[unaccompanied homelessness]] in the U.S. Chapin Hall partnered with twenty-two counties across the U.S. to conduct "youth-led counts and surveys of young people and providers".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/fss/provdrs/emerg/news/2016/march/chicago-joins-twenty-two-communities-across-the-country-join-voi.html|title=City of Chicago :: Chicago Joins Twenty-two Communities Across the Country Join Voices of Youth Count|website=www.cityofchicago.org|language=en|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref> The research also included qualitative interviews in five of those twenty-two counties, a national phone survey, a survey of service providers, a review of policy related to youth homelessness, and a systematic review of published evidence on the effectiveness of programs targeting youth homelessness.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://voicesofyouthcount.org/approach/|title=Approach – Voices of Youth Count|website=voicesofyouthcount.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref>
Based on these data sources, Voices of Youth Count has produced a series of policy briefs. The first provided an estimate of the scale and character of youth homelessness in the U.S.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://voicesofyouthcount.org/brief/national-estimates-of-youth-homelessness/|title=Missed Opportunities: Youth Homelessness in America|last=Morton|first=Matthew|date=November 2017|website=Voices of Youth Count|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref> The second report focused on lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans, and queer youth,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://voicesofyouthcount.org/brief/lgbtq-youth-homelessness|title=Missed Opportunities: LGBTQ Youth Homelessness in America|last=Morton|first=Matthew|date=April 2018|website=Voices of Youth Count|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref> and the third looked at youth homelessness among pregnant or parenting young people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://voicesofyouthcount.org/brief/pregnant-and-parenting-youth-experiencing-homelessness/|title=Missed Opportunities: Pregnant and Parenting Youth Experiencing Homelessness in America|last=Dworsky|first=Amy|date=April 2018|website=Voices of Youth Count|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref>
Reports on youth counts, youth homelessness in the rural U.S., youth trajectories into and through homelessness, child welfare, and education are forthcoming.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://voicesofyouthcount.org/more-research-to-impact-briefs-to-come/|title=More Research to Impact Briefs to Come|last=|first=|date=|website=Voices of Youth Count|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref>
== Organization == Chapin Hall employs research and policy staff with experience in child welfare, epidemiology, psychology, social work, statistics, and youth development.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.chapinhall.org/experts/|title=Experts|last=|first=|date=|website=Chapin Hall|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref> The organization began with 15 employees in 1986,<ref name=":1" /> and has had more than one hundred employees as of 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/362/362167012/362167012_201406_990.pdf|title=Form 990 – Return of Organization Exempt from Income Tax|last=|first=|date=2013|website=Foundation Center|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref> Annual revenue in 1986 was about five hundred thousand.<ref name=":1" /> In 2016, that number stood at over five million dollars.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.govwiki.info/pdfs/Non-Profit/IL%20Chapin%20Hall%20Center%20For%20Children%202016.pdf|title=Chapin Hall Center for Children: Financial Statements and Independent Auditor's Reports Required by Government Auditing Standards and Uniform Guidance|last=|first=|date=February 2017|website=GovWiki|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref>
Bryan Samuels is the current Executive Director of Chapin Hall. He joined the organization in 2013 after serving as the commissioner of the Administration on Children, Youth and Families in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington D.C.]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://chronicleofsocialchange.org/featured/bryan-samuels-leaving-hhs-to-lead-chapin-hall|title=Bryan Samuels Leaving HHS to Lead Chapin Hall|last=|first=|date=2013-08-06|work=The Chronicle of Social Change|access-date=2018-07-13|language=en-US}}</ref> In 2018, Samuels was the recipient of the Bernice Weissbourd Award for Family Support, awarded by Family Focus.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.family-focus.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/Family-Focus-2018-Anniversary-Gala-Bryan-Samuels-Award-Comments.pdf|title=Bryan Samuels Comments: Recipient of the 2018 Bernice Weissbourd Award for Family Support|last=|first=|date=May 15, 2018|website=Family Focus|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 13, 2018}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Children's charities based in the United States]] [[Category:Think tanks based in the United States]] [[Category:Social care in the United States]] [[Category:1860 establishments in Illinois]] [[Category:Youth charities]] [[Category:Human welfare organizations based in Chicago]] [[Category:University of Chicago]] [[Category:Social welfare charities based in the United States]] [[Category:Foster care in the United States]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Commotio cordis | synonyms = | image = Heart-thorax-gray.gif | caption = Human adult thorax, showing the outline of the heart (in red). The sensitive zone for mechanical induction of heart rhythm disturbances lies between the 2nd and the 4th ribs, to the left of the sternum | pronounce = | field = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }}
'''Commotio cordis''' ([[Latin]], "agitation of the heart") is an often lethal disruption of [[heart rhythm]] that occurs as a result of a blow to the area directly over the heart (the [[precordium|precordial region]]), at a critical time during the cycle of a heart beat causing [[cardiac arrest]]. It is a form of [[ventricular fibrillation]] (V-Fib), not mechanical damage to the heart muscle or surrounding organs, and not the result of heart disease. The fatality rate is about 65% even with prompt [[CPR]] and [[defibrillation]], and more than 80% without.<ref name="Maron BJ, Estes NA 3rd 2010 917–27">{{cite journal | vauthors = Maron BJ, Estes NA | title = Commotio cordis | journal = The New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 362 | issue = 10 | pages = 917–27 | date = March 2010 | pmid = 20220186 | doi = 10.1056/NEJMra0910111 }}</ref><ref name="lacrosse"/>
Commotio cordis occurs mostly in boys and young men (average age 15), usually during [[sport]]s, most frequently baseball, often despite a chest protector. It is usually caused by a projectile, but can also be caused by the blow of an elbow or other body part. Being less developed, the thorax of an adolescent is likely more prone to this injury given the circumstances.
The phenomenon was confirmed experimentally in the 1930s, with research in anaesthetized [[rabbit]]s, [[cat]]s and [[dog]]s.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Schlomka G |title=Commotio cordis und ihre Folgen. Die Einwirkung stumpfer Brustwandtraumen auf das Herz |journal=Ergebnisse der inneren Medizin und Kinderheilkunde |date=1934 |volume=47 |pages=1–91 |doi=10.1007/978-3-642-90672-5_1}}</ref>
==Causes==
=== Sport === Commotio cordis is a very rare event, but nonetheless is often considered when an athlete presents with [[Sudden cardiac death of athletes|sudden cardiac death]]. Some of the sports which have a risk for this cause of trauma are [[baseball]], [[American football]], [[association football]], [[ice hockey]], [[polo]], [[rugby football]], [[cricket]], [[softball]], [[Basque pelota|pelota]], [[fencing]], [[lacrosse]], [[boxing]], [[karate]], [[kung fu]], and other [[martial arts]]. [[Child]]ren are especially vulnerable, possibly{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} due to the mechanical properties of their [[thorax|thoracic skeleton]]. From 1996 to spring 2007, the [[United States|USA]] National Commotio Cordis Registry had 188 cases recorded, with about half occurring during [[organized sport]]s.<ref name="lacrosse">{{cite web |url=http://www.uslacrosse.org/safety/sudden-cardiac-arrest-aeds-commotio-cordis/position-statement-on-commotio-cordis |title=Position Statement on Commotio Cordis |publisher=[[US Lacrosse]] |date=January 2008 |accessdate=22 February 2017}}</ref> Almost all (96%) of the victims were male, the mean age of the victims during that period was 14.7 years, and fewer than one in five survived the incident.<ref name="lacrosse" />
===Other situations=== Commotio cordis may also occur in other situations, such as in children who are punished with blows over the precordium, cases of [[torture]], and frontal collisions of [[motor vehicle]]s (the impact of the steering wheel against the thorax, although this has decreased substantially with the use of [[safety belt]]s and [[air bag]]s). In one fatality, the impact to the chest was the result of an exploding [[Whipped cream|whipped cream]] canister.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.self.com/story/rebecca-burger-whipped-cream-dispenser-death|title=Fitness Blogger Rebecca Burger Died After a Whipped Cream Dispenser Exploded|last=Barnes|first=Zahra|work=SELF|access-date=2017-07-14|language=en}}</ref>
In contrast, the [[precordial thump]] (hard blows given over the precordium with a closed fist to revert [[cardiac arrest]]) is a sanctioned procedure for emergency resuscitation by trained health professionals witnessing a monitored arrest when no equipment is at hand, endorsed by the latest guidelines of the [[International Liaison Committee on Resuscitation]]. It has been discussed controversially, as—in particular in severe hypoxia—it may cause the opposite effect (i.e., a worsening of rhythm—commotio cordis). In a normal adult, the energy range involved in the precordial thump is five to 10 times below that associated with commotio cordis.<ref name="Kohl2005">Kohl P, Sachs F & Franz M (eds): ''Cardiac Mechano-Electric Feedback and Arrhythmias: from Pipette to Patient''. Elsevier (Saunders), Philadelphia 2005.</ref>
==Mechanism == [[Image:Commotio Cordis Risk Zone.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Diagram showing the portion of normal sinus rhythm during which commotio cordis is a risk]]
These factors influence the chance of commotio cordis:
* Direction of impact over the precordium (precise area, angle of impact) * Total applied energy (area of impact versus energy, i.e., the [[kinetic energy]] of the projectile <math>E_\text{k} =\tfrac{1}{2} mv^2 </math>) * Impact occurring within a specific 10– to 30-millisecond portion of the cardiac cycle. This period occurs in the ascending phase of the T wave, when the ventricular myocardium is repolarizing, moving from [[Systole (medicine)|systole]] to [[diastole]] (relaxation).
The small window of vulnerability explains why it is a rare event. Considering that the total cardiac cycle has a duration of 1 second (for a base cardiac frequency of 60 beats per minute), the probability of a mechanical trauma within the window of vulnerability is 1 to 3% only. That also explains why the heart becomes more vulnerable when it is physically strained by sports activities: # The increase in heart rate (exercise [[tachycardia]]) may double the probability above (e.g., with 120 beats per minute the cardiac cycle shortens to 500 milliseconds without fundamentally altering the window-of-vulnerability's size) # Relative exercise-induced [[Hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]] and acceleration of the excitoconductive system of the heart make it more susceptible to stretch-induced ventricular fibrillation.
The [[cell (biology)|cellular]] mechanisms of commotio cordis are still poorly understood, but probably related to the activation of mechanosensitive proteins, [[ion channels]]. These trigger extra electrical excitation waves which, if occurring right at the trailing edge of a previous electrical cycle, can give rise to ventricular fibrillation.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Quinn|first=T. Alexander|last2=Jin|first2=Honghua|last3=Lee|first3=Peter|last4=Kohl|first4=Peter|date=2017-08-01|title=Mechanically Induced Ectopy via Stretch-Activated Cation-Nonselective Channels Is Caused by Local Tissue Deformation and Results in Ventricular Fibrillation if Triggered on the Repolarization Wave Edge (Commotio Cordis)|url=http://circep.ahajournals.org/content/10/8/e004777|journal=Circulation: Arrhythmia and Electrophysiology|language=en|volume=10|issue=8|pages=e004777|doi=10.1161/CIRCEP.116.004777|issn=1941-3149}}</ref> Since the trailing edge of the preceding electrical cycle travels over the ventricular surface, the critical window for mechanical induction of ventricular fibrillation varies locally - i.e. the commotio cordis risk window exists in time and in space.<ref name=":0" /> This helps to explain why precordial impacts tend to have benign consequences.
Impact energies of at least 50 [[joule]]s are estimated to be required to cause cardiac arrest, when applied in the right time and spot of the precordium of an adult.<ref name="Kohl2005" /> Impacts up to 130 joules have already been measured with [[hockey puck]]s and lacrosse balls, 450 joules in karate punches, and 1028 joules in boxer [[Rocky Marciano]]'s punch.<ref name="titlescience.ca View question #821">{{cite web |url=http://www.science.ca/askascientist/viewquestion.php?qID=821 |title=science.ca View question #821 |accessdate=2008-02-23 |format= |work=}}</ref> The 50-joule threshold, however, can be considerably lowered when the victim's heart is under [[ischemia|ischemic]] conditions, such as in [[coronary artery]] insufficiency.<ref name="Kohl2005" />
Also an upper limit of impact energy is applied to the heart; too much energy will create structural damage to the heart muscle, as well as causing electrical upset. This condition is referred to as [[contuiso cordis|contusio cordis]] (from Latin for bruising of the heart). On isolated [[guinea pig]] hearts, as little as 5 [[millijoule|mJ]] were needed to induce release of [[creatine kinase]], a marker for [[muscle cell]] damage.<ref name="pmid16125216">{{cite journal | vauthors = Cooper PJ, Epstein A, Macleod IA, Schaaf ST, Sheldon J, Boulin C, Kohl P | title = Soft tissue impact characterisation kit (STICK) for ex situ investigation of heart rhythm responses to acute mechanical stimulation | journal = Progress in Biophysics and Molecular Biology | volume = 90 | issue = 1-3 | pages = 444–68 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16125216 | doi = 10.1016/j.pbiomolbio.2005.07.004 }}</ref> Obviously, this figure does not include the dissipation of energy through the chest wall, and is not scaled up for humans, but it is indicative that relatively small amounts of energy are required to reach the heart before physical damage is done.
==Prevention==
The risk would probably be reduced by improved coaching techniques, such as teaching young batters to turn away from the ball to avoid errant pitches, according to doctors. Defensive players in lacrosse and hockey are now taught to avoid using their chest to block the ball or puck. Starting in 2017, high school lacrosse players are penalized, and play stopped immediately, if they enter their own goal crease with the apparent intent of blocking shots or acting as goalkeeper.<ref name="NFHS lacrosse rule 4.18.4">Rule 4.18.4, {{cite book |title=2018 Boys' Lacrosse Rule Book |date=2018 |publisher=[[National Federation of State High School Associations]] |location=[[Indianapolis, Indiana]] |page=47}}</ref>
Chest protectors and vests are designed to reduce trauma from blunt bodily injury, but this does not offer protection from commotio cordis and may offer a false sense of security. Almost 20% of the victims in competitive football, baseball, lacrosse and hockey were wearing protectors. This ineffectiveness has been confirmed by animal studies. Development of adequate chest protectors may prove difficult.<ref name="Maron BJ, Estes NA 3rd 2010 917–27"/>
==Treatment== [[File:Medtronic aed training kit.jpg|thumb|right|Defibrillator training kit]]
Most cases are fatal. [[Automated external defibrillator]]s have helped increase the survival rate to 35%.<ref name="Maron BJ, Estes NA 3rd 2010 917–27"/> Defibrillation must be started as soon as possible (within 3 minutes) for maximal benefit. Commotio cordis is the leading cause of fatalities in youth baseball in the US, with two to three deaths per year.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Abrunzo TJ | title = Commotio cordis. The single, most common cause of traumatic death in youth baseball | journal = American Journal of Diseases of Children | volume = 145 | issue = 11 | pages = 1279–82 | date = November 1991 | pmid = 1951221 | doi = 10.1001/archpedi.1991.02160110071023 }}</ref> It has been recommended that "communities and [[school district]]s reexamine the need for accessible automatic defibrillators and cardiopulmonary resuscitation-trained [[coach (sports)|coach]]es at organized sporting events for children."<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Salib EA, Cyran SE, Cilley RE, Maron BJ, Thomas NJ | title = Efficacy of bystander cardiopulmonary resuscitation and out-of-hospital automated external defibrillation as life-saving therapy in commotio cordis | journal = The Journal of Pediatrics | volume = 147 | issue = 6 | pages = 863–6 | date = December 2005 | pmid = 16356450 | doi = 10.1016/j.jpeds.2005.07.041 }}</ref>
==Legal issues==
Several people have been convicted of involuntary [[manslaughter]] in cases involving insufficient and slow medical help to athletes who experienced commotio cordis during sports events,<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Maron BJ, Mitten MJ, Greene Burnett C | title = Criminal consequences of commotio cordis | journal = The American Journal of Cardiology | volume = 89 | issue = 2 | pages = 210–3 | date = January 2002 | pmid = 11792344 | doi = 10.1016/S0002-9149(01)02202-0 }}</ref> as well as in cases of intentional delivery of contusive blows. In 1992, Italian hockey player Miran Schrott died after a blow to his chest from the stick of Canadian-Italian player Jimmy Boni. Boni was charged with [[culpable homicide]], and eventually pleaded guilty to manslaughter, paying a $1,300 fine and $175,000 restitution to Schrott's family.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Maki|first1=Allan|title=Darcy Robinson's death brings shock|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/darcy-robinsons-death-brings-shock/article1083411/|accessdate=29 February 2016|publisher=The Globe and Mail|date=28 September 2007}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Pulmonary contusion]] * [[Touch of Death]] * [[Commotio thoracis]]

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Medical and health organisations based in Turkey to [[:Category:Medical and health organizations based in Turkey]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox religious building | building_name = Complex of Sultan Bayezid II Health Museum | native_name = Sultan II. Bayezid Külliyesi Sağlık Müzesi | image = Edirne 7349 Nevit.JPG | image_size = | caption = | coordinates = {{coord|41|41|09|N|26|32|37|E|type:landmark_region:TR-22|display=inline,title}} | map_type = | map_size = | map_caption = | location = [[Edirne]], Turkey | geo = | latitude = | longitude = | religious_affiliation = [[Islam]] | status = | functional_status = Museum | heritage_designation = | leadership = | website = | architecture = yes | architect = | architecture_type = Mosque | architecture_style = [[Islamic architecture|Islamic]], [[Ottoman architecture]] | capacity = | length = | width = | dome_quantity = | dome_height_outer = | general_contractor = | facade_direction = | covered_area = | groundbreaking = 1484 | year_completed = 1488 | minaret_quantity = 2 | minaret_height = | spire_quantity = | spire_height = | materials = }}
[[File:Beyazit kulliyesi.JPG|thumb|The inner courtyard of the darüşşifa]] The '''Complex of Sultan Bayezid II Health Museum''' ({{lang-tr|Sultan II Bayezid Külliyesi Sağlık Müzesi}}) is a hospital museum of [[Trakya University]] within the Complex of Sultan Bayezid II located in [[Edirne]], Turkey.
A ''[[külliye]]'' is an [[Ottoman architecture|Ottoman architectural]] term for a complex of buildings centered on a [[mosque]]. Complex of Bayezid II Külliye was built in 1488 by the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] sultan [[Bayezid II]] (reigned 1481–1512).
The complex contains a [[Dar al-Shifa]] (Turkish ''darüşşifa'', "hospital, medical center"), and it remained in operation for four centuries from 1488 until the [[Russo-Turkish War (1877–78)]]. The hospital was especially notable for its treatment methods for [[mental disorder]]s, which included the use of music, water sound and scents.
The historic darüşşifa was incorporated into the structure of Edirne-based [[Trakya University]] in 1993, and converted into a "Health Museum" ({{lang-tr|Sağlık Müzesi}}) in 1997, a museum dedicated to the [[history of medicine]] and health matters in general. It has been developing constantly ever since. It remains Turkey's only museum in its field and provides varied and valuable information to visitors on the development of [[medicine]] and of medical services throughout history, especially Ottoman history. The museum is the second most visited historical site in Edirne after the [[Selimiye Mosque]]. The museum was awarded the [[European Council]]'s "[[European Council]] Museum Award" in 2004 and in 2016 the complex was inscribed in the [[List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey_(Tentative_list)|Tentative list of World Heritage Sites in Turkey]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Kızılırmak Delta Wetland and Bird Sanctuary |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/6117/ | website=UNESCO World Heritage Centre | accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref>
==Medical school== [[File:ComplexSultanBayezidIIEdirne (2).JPG|thumb|Courtyard of the historic Medical school.]] [[File:HealthMuseumEdirne (2).JPG|thumb|left|150px|Information plaque about the Medical school]]
The health institution was a [[medical school]] ({{lang-ota|Medrese-i Etibba}}). It ranked among the best 60 schools ([[madrasa]]) in the [[Ottoman Empire]] due to its high-paid scholar.
The medical school consisted of 18 student rooms and a classroom surrounding three sides of a courtyard with a [[shadirvan]] (fountain) in the middle. Famous Ottoman travel writer [[Evliya Çelebi]] (1611–after 1682) mentions in his book that the students of the medical school were mature physicians, who studied and discussed works of [[Ancient Greek]] philosophers, scientists and physicians such as [[Plato]] (428/427 or 424/423–348/347 BC), [[Socrates]] (470/469–399 BC), [[Philip of Opus]], [[Aristotle]] (384–322 BC), [[Galen]] (AD 129– c. 200/c. 216) and [[Pythagoras]] (c. 570 – c. 495 BC). The physicians, each being a specialist in a different field, tried to find out the best treatment by studying valuable scientific literature on medicine. The books of the medical school are archived in the hand-written books library of Selimiye Mosque today.
According to Evliya Çelebi, following daily wages were paid to the staff and students: * Scholar (1): 60 [[akçe]] (silver coin) including holidays, * Assistant (1): 7 akçe * Library clerk (1): 2 akçe * Servants (2): 2 akçe * Students (18): 2 akçe. in addition to meeting of all their needs.
==References== <references /> ==External links== * [http://www.trakya.edu.tr/kulliye_ing/ Museum website] {{en icon}} {{commons category|Complex of Sultan Bayezid II Health Museum}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bayezid II Kulliye Health Museum}} [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1488]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Edirne]] [[Category:Biographical museums in Turkey]] [[Category:Hospital museums]] [[Category:Defunct hospitals]] [[Category:Ottoman architecture in Edirne]] [[Category:1877 disestablishments]] [[Category:Trakya University]] [[Category:Museums established in 1997]] [[Category:Museums in Edirne Province]] [[Category:Ottoman museums]] [[Category:Ottoman hospitals]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Turkey]]

{{BLP primary sources|date=March 2010}}
{{Infobox writer | image=Diane portrait at 300.jpg | caption = Stanley in 2002 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1943|12|27}} | birth_place = [[Abilene, Texas]], USA | nationality = American | occupation = {{Flatlist| * Writer * illustrator * graphic designer }} | genre = {{Flatlist| * Children's books * [[fantasy]] }} | subject = Medical illustration | website = {{URL|dianestanley.com}} }}
'''Diane Stanley''' (born December 27, 1943)<ref name=stanley-bio/> is an American [[children's literature|children's]] [[author]] and [[illustrator]].
==Life and work==
Stanley was born in [[Abilene, Texas]].<ref name="stanley-bio">{{cite web|url=http://dianestanley.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/10/Extended-Biography1.pdf|title=Diane Stanley: Extended Biography|accessdate=2011-11-25|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120422151653/http://dianestanley.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/10/Extended-Biography1.pdf|archivedate=2012-04-22|df=}}</ref> She earned her bachelor's degree from [[Trinity University (Texas)|Trinity University]] and her M. A. in medical illustration from [[Johns Hopkins University]] College of Medicine. She has worked as a [[medical illustrator]], a [[graphic designer]] for Dell Publishing, and an [[art director]] for G. P. Putnam's Sons, winning three design awards from the [[New York Book Show]].
Stanley is the author and/or illustrator of fifty books for children, noted especially for her series of picture book biographies. ''Shaka, King of the Zulus'' was named a New York Times Best Illustrated Book and ''Leonardo da Vinci'' received the [[Orbis Pictus Award]] for Outstanding Nonfiction from the National Council for Teachers of English. Many of her books have been honored as [[American Library Association Notable Books]] and she has twice received both the Boston Globe/Hornbook Award and the Society of Children's Book Writers' [[Golden Kite Award]]. She was the recipient of the Washington Post/Children's Book Guild Award for the body of her work.
She has three grown children and lives in Santa Fe, New Mexico with her husband, Peter Vennema. ==Books==

|website=worldcat.org |publisher=Online Computer Library Center |accessdate=November 19, 2016}}</ref> *[[Peter the Great]], Four Winds Press (1986)<ref>{{cite web <!-- Article title: '''East Gordon Street Sewerage Works''' siteId: 29134 placeRef:602727 --> {{Use Australian English|date=January 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox historic site | name = East Gordon Street Sewerage Works | image = East Gordon Street Sewerage Works, 2006.jpg | caption = East Gordon Street Sewerage Works, 2006 | locmapin = Queensland#Australia | map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|-21.1444|149.1929|region:AU-QLD_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | location = Sewerage Works Buildings, 38 East Gordon Street, [[Mackay, Queensland|Mackay]], [[Mackay Region]], [[Queensland]], Australia | beginning_label = Design period | beginning_date = 1919 - 1930s (interwar period) | built = 1936 | built_for = | demolished = | architect = [[A E Harding Frew]] | architecture = | owner = | designation1 = Queensland Heritage Register | designation1_offname = East Gordon Street Sewerage Works, Pump Stations | designation1_type = state heritage (built) | designation1_date = 10 July 2009 | delisted1_date = | designation1_partof = | designation1_number = 602727 | designation1_free1name = Significant period | designation1_free1value = 1936- | designation1_free2name = Significant components | designation1_free2value = | designation1_free3name = Builders | designation1_free3value = }}
'''East Gordon Street Sewerage Works''' is a heritage-listed [[pumping station]] at Sewerage Works Buildings, 38 East Gordon Street, [[Mackay, Queensland|Mackay]], [[Mackay Region]], [[Queensland]], Australia. It was designed by [[A E Harding Frew]] and built in 1936. It is also known as Pump Stations. It was added to the [[Queensland Heritage Register]] on 10 July 2009.<ref name=qhr>{{cite QHR|29134|East Gordon Street Sewerage Works|602727|accessdate=1 August 2014}}</ref>
== History == The sewerage works in East Gordon Street, one of the first in Queensland, was opened by George Moody, [[City of Mackay|Mayor of Mackay]], on 25 January 1936. The consulting engineer was AE Harding Frew.<ref name=qhr/>
Mackay began as a settlement on the south bank of the [[Pioneer River]] serving pastoral holdings. By 1863 it had been surveyed and the first lots of land sold. It was gazetted as a [[port of entry]] and a [[Mackay Customs House|customs house]] was opened. [[Sugarcane|Sugar cane]] was introduced in 1865 and by the mid-1880s this was the major industry in the area. Mackay prospered as a port and as a commercial and administrative centre.<ref name=qhr/>
From the end of the nineteenth century until well after [[World War II]], basic services in regional Queensland were progressively upgraded. Reticulated water supplies, sewerage systems and electricity were introduced into regional towns beginning with the major centres. Planning for [[Brisbane]]'s sewerage system was underway by 1909. A sewerage scheme was introduced at [[Toowoomba]] in 1925, and development of a sewerage scheme at [[Rockhampton]] commenced in 1936. Most other regional centres did not have sewerage systems provided until after World War Two, with some local government areas waiting until the 1960s-1980s. Mackay's sewerage system, opened in January 1936, was among the first in regional Queensland.<ref name=qhr/>
The system was introduced at a time when Mackay was undergoing a major public works program to improve the infrastructure of the town and upgrade the harbour. A number of factors prompted this program. Through the 1920s and 1930s, Mackay enjoyed a period of substantial growth, even during the period of financial hardship and unemployment caused by the [[Great Depression in Australia|Depression]]. It was the fastest-growing town in Queensland, with its population almost doubling between 1923 and 1940. This was largely due to the linking of Mackay by the [[North Coast railway line, Queensland|North Coast railway line]] to Rockhampton in 1921 and to [[Townsville]] in 1923. This improved access to markets and reduced transport costs, boosting not only the sugar industry, but also the developing dairy and tourist industries.<ref name=qhr/>
Another contributing factor was that the local [[Members of the Queensland Legislative Assembly|Member of the Queensland Legislative Assembly]], [[William Forgan Smith]], was [[Premier of Queensland]] between 1932 and 1940 and he supported the growth of the region. It was hoped that the public works program, including the Outer Harbour scheme, would make Mackay one of Queensland's most frequented beauty spots and that, as an attractive modern city, it would become a base for those visiting [[Eungella]] and the islands.<ref name=qhr/>
The city council commissioned a town plan from Ronald McInnes in 1934. It was based on Britain's Town Planning Act of 1932 and was the first town plan designed for an existing city in Queensland, serving as a model for other cities for many years. The [[City of Mackay|Mackay City Council]] undertook an ambitious plan for the beautification and modernisation of the city. The scheme included the provision of new parks, kerbing and channelling, new water mains, a new powerhouse and the establishment of the sewerage system.<ref name=qhr/>
At the opening of the East Gordon Street Sewerage Works on 25 January 1936 the chairman of the Mackay Harbour Board, Charles Frederick Bagley, paid tribute to the city council for its initiative in carrying out the scheme and to the consulting engineer AE Harding Frew who designed it.<ref name=qhr/>
Alison Eavis Harding Frew (1883-1952) was a prominent Queensland civil engineer. Harding Frew's designed about 80 bridges throughout Queensland during his career. He was a consulting engineer in [[Melbourne]] during the 1920s and on the [[Pyrmont Power House]] at [[Sydney]] in the early 1940s. He was a consultant on the 1926 Brisbane Cross River Commission and was the designing engineer for the [[William Jolly Bridge]] in Brisbane, from November 1926 to 1932. From 1932 to 1935 he was the engineer for bridge construction on the [[Hornibrook Bridge|Hornibrook Highway]] project, the bridge linking [[Sandgate, Queensland|Sandgate]] and [[Redcliffe, Queensland|Redcliffe]]. Frew's design for the fully automated pump houses at Mackay, featuring castellated parapets, encompasses one of the basic principles of civil engineering, which is to design creative solutions that are both functional and aesthetically pleasing.<ref name=qhr/>
At the opening of the works Bagley reiterated the view of the day that, with the completion of the sewerage works and the Outer Harbour Scheme, Mackay would become even more important, and the Government Medical Officer, Dr Ernest Wesley Chenoweth, emphasised the public health advantages of the new sewerage scheme.<ref name=qhr/>
Sewage was pumped to the site via concrete or glazed pipes, where it was held in a well and treated with [[chlorine]] before being pumped out to sea at high tide. The main elements of sewage treatment included the separation of solids from fluids by screening and allowing the solids to settle in a tank. The solids were drawn off and disposed of, and the fluids were often treated before being discharged into a waterway or the ocean. Chlorine was used as a disinfectant.<ref name=qhr/>
By December 1933 a total of {{convert|68123|ft}} of sewer main, including a main crossing at Sandfly Creek near the East Gordon Street site, had been pegged out. Tenders had also been let for the construction of the pump well and pump house, the supply and installation of pump machinery, and the construction of the chlorinator.<ref name=qhr/>
The smaller building (the chlorinator) toward the front of the site is now used for storage. The larger building is still in use as a pump station with a submersible pump external to the structure and a switchboard inside the building. A modern [[deodoriser]] has been installed next to this building. Sewage is pumped from the station at East Gordon Street to a pump station in Sydney Street.<ref name=qhr/>
The East Gordon Street works forms part of a major network of 135 pump stations throughout Mackay and they are associated with a sewer main of more than {{convert|630|km|mi}}, which ultimately connects to one of three waste water treatment plants in the city. Mackay Water, a business unit of [[Mackay City Council]] (now of the Mackay Regional Council), is responsible for the management of Mackay's sewerage scheme.<ref name=qhr/>
== Description == The 1936 Sewerage Works is located on a level allotment in East Gordon Street, Mackay. The two principal early structures on the site are the pump house and chlorinator building. These are small, white, concrete buildings with castellated parapets. The larger is to the rear and the smaller to the front of the block.<ref name=qhr/>
The buildings are constructed from off-form concrete with a horizontal, wide-board pattern showing. Vent stacks are built as miniature towers at some corners of the structures; other corners have matching engaged [[buttress]]es. They sit on concrete tanks, their floors about {{convert|1.5|m}} above the ground.<ref name=qhr/>
The smaller building (chlorinator) is rectangular in plan with the longer elevations facing south-west and north-east. Two square, metal-framed windows, covered with metal shutters open into both of these elevations. A square window into the north-west elevation is also covered with sheeting. The entrance to the building, in the south-east elevation, is via a concrete stair which ascends parallel to the wall finishing at a concrete landing. A wooden door opens from the landing. This is secured with a knob and a more recent lock. The top of the tank under the smaller building forms a raised semicircular concrete [[plinth]] which extends to the south-west. The tank contains a chamber with a tapered floor.<ref name=qhr/>
Internally, the building comprises a single room with unpainted concrete walls. It contains two large items of early machinery. One of these has a small brass name plate bearing the words "Filtration and water softening system".<ref name=qhr/>
The larger building (pump house) is also rectangular in plan with the long elevations facing south-west and north-east. Access to the building is via a concrete stair to the narrow, south-east elevation. The stair ascends at right angles to the wall finishing at a long landing. At the top of the landing, a double metal door opens into the interior. It has a curved handle and is secured by a barrel bolt. A plaque above the door commemorates the commissioning of the works on 25 January 1936. The opposite elevation has a single small, metal- framed glass window with nine panes.<ref name=qhr/>
The south-west elevation has three square, steel-framed windows. These pivot around a horizontal axis at mid-height. The top of the tank attached to the side of the building projects to form a rectangular plinth. A steel stairway ascends at right angles to the south-eastern side of the tank finishing close to the wall of the building. Four metal shafts project from the top of the tank. Three of these have metal wheels fitted to the top; threaded lengths of rod extend above these wheels. Hinged, steel panels provide access into the tanks.<ref name=qhr/>
The opposite (north-east) elevation has two square windows and a narrow hatchway around {{convert|1.5|m}} in height. The windows are covered with sheeting which is boxed out from the wall a short distance. Two metal plates are bolted over the hatchway; a large square plate above a smaller rectangular one. Both plates have curved handles at each end.<ref name=qhr/>
The top of the tank forms a rectangular plinth extending from this elevation. There are small rectangular and arched openings into the base of the north-eastern end of the plinth.<ref name=qhr/>
Internally, the larger building is painted light grey on the lower part of the wall and pale green above, separated by a black band. The floor comprises a series of steel plates with a metal ladder descending to a sub-floor area that is now disused. The building contains a grey cabinet housing electrical equipment. This is not considered to be of cultural heritage significance.<ref name=qhr/>
The building also contains a manually operated overhead crane. Transverse movement of the crane is achieved by means of a simple chain and wheel mechanism. A similar chain and wheel raises and lowers a hook. This mechanism comprises a pulley and two back-to-back hooks. One of the hooks secures the mechanism to the overhead cross beam of the crane; the other dangles downwards for holding the load.<ref name=qhr/>
== Heritage listing == East Gordon Street Sewerage Works was listed on the [[Queensland Heritage Register]] on 10 July 2009 having satisfied the following criteria.<ref name=qhr/>
'''The place is important in demonstrating the evolution or pattern of Queensland's history.'''
The East Gordon Street Sewerage Works in Mackay, opened in 1936, was one of the first in regional Queensland. As such, it is important in demonstrating the progressive upgrading of basic infrastructure in regional Queensland, in particular the provision of sewerage schemes, which took place in regional towns and cities from the interwar period. Most other regional centres did not develop such schemes until after World War II, with some local government areas not constructing sewerage infrastructure until after 1960.<ref name=qhr/>
As one of the first sewerage works in regional Queensland, it is tangible evidence of the importance of Mackay as a regional centre in the 1930s and the influence the city enjoyed through their local Member of Parliament, William Forgan Smith, who was Premier at the time. During the 1920s and 1930s, Mackay was the fastest growing town in Queensland.<ref name=qhr/>
'''The place is important in demonstrating the principal characteristics of a particular class of cultural places.'''
The place is important in demonstrating the principal characteristics of a sewage treatment works of the interwar period. Characteristics include pump house, chlorination plant building, and the deliberate attempt to visually disguise the true purpose of these structures through the stylistic treatment of the exterior walls with their castellated parapets, which is unusual for such utilitarian structures.<ref name=qhr/>
The place also is important in demonstrating the work of prominent civil engineer AE Harding Frew, who designed the scheme. Frew made a substantial contribution to civil engineering infrastructure in Queensland including designing the William Jolly Bridge in Brisbane.<ref name=qhr/>

[[File:Thermotoga maritima encapsulin.png|thumb|Crystal structure of [[Thermotoga maritima]] [[encapsulin]]. PDB entry {{PDBe|3dkt}}]]
'''Encapsulin nanocompartments''', or '''encapsulin protein cages''', are spherical bacterial organelle-like compartments roughly 25-30 nm in diameter that are involved in various aspects of metabolism, in particular protecting bacteria from oxidative stress. Encapsulin nanocompartments are structurally similar to the [[HK97|HK97 bacteriophage]] and their function depends on the proteins loaded into the nanocompartment.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nichols|first=Robert J.|last2=Cassidy-Amstutz|first2=Caleb|last3=Chaijarasphong|first3=Thawatchai|last4=Savage|first4=David F.|date=October 2017|title=Encapsulins: molecular biology of the shell|journal=Critical Reviews in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology|volume=52|issue=5|pages=583–594|doi=10.1080/10409238.2017.1337709|issn=1549-7798|pmid=28635326}}</ref> The sphere is formed from 60 (for a 25 nm sphere) or 180 (for a 30 nm sphere) copies of a single [[protomer]], termed encapsulin. Their structure has been studied in great detail using [[X-ray crystallography]]<ref name="Sutter 2008">{{cite journal|last1=Sutter|first1=M|last2=Boehringer|first2=D|last3=Gutmann|first3=S|last4=Günther|first4=S|last5=Prangishvili|first5=D|last6=Loessner|first6=MJ|last7=Stetter|first7=KO|last8=Weber-Ban|first8=E|last9=Ban|first9=N|title=Structural basis of enzyme encapsulation into a bacterial nanocompartment.|journal=Nature Structural & Molecular Biology|date=September 2008|volume=15|issue=9|pages=939–47|doi=10.1038/nsmb.1473|pmid=19172747}}</ref> and [[cryo-electron microscopy]].<ref name="McHugh 2014">{{cite journal|last1=McHugh|first1=CA|last2=Fontana|first2=J|last3=Nemecek|first3=D|last4=Cheng|first4=N|last5=Aksyuk|first5=AA|last6=Heymann|first6=JB|last7=Winkler|first7=DC|last8=Lam|first8=AS|last9=Wall|first9=JS|date=1 September 2014|title=A virus capsid-like nanocompartment that stores iron and protects bacteria from oxidative stress.|journal=The EMBO Journal|volume=33|issue=17|pages=1896–911|doi=10.15252/embj.201488566|pmc=4195785|pmid=25024436|last10=Steven|first10=AC|last11=Hoiczyk|first11=E}}</ref>
A number of different types of proteins have been identified as being loaded into encapsulin nanocompartments. [[Peroxidase]]s or proteins similar to [[ferritin]]s are the two most common types of cargo proteins.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Giessen|first=Tobias W.|last2=Silver|first2=Pamela A.|date=2017-03-06|title=Widespread distribution of encapsulin nanocompartments reveals functional diversity|journal=Nature Microbiology|volume=2|pages=17029|doi=10.1038/nmicrobiol.2017.29|issn=2058-5276|pmid=28263314}}</ref> While most encapsulin nanocompartments contain only one type of cargo protein, in some species two or three types of cargo proteins are loaded.<ref name="Sutter 2008" /><ref name="McHugh 2014" /><ref name=":1" />
Encapsulins purified from ''Rhodococcus jostii'' can be assembled and disassembled with changes in pH. In the assembled state, the compartment enhances the activity of its cargo, a peroxidase enzyme.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Assembly in vitro of Rhodococcus jostii RHA1 encapsulin and peroxidase DypB to form a nanocompartment|journal = The FEBS Journal|date = 2013-05-01|issn = 1742-4658|pmid = 23560779|pages = 2097–2104|volume = 280|issue = 9|doi = 10.1111/febs.12234|first = Rahman|last = Rahmanpour|first2 = Timothy D. H.|last2 = Bugg}}</ref>
==Use as a platform for bioengineering== Recently, encapsulin nanocompartments have begun to receive considerable interest from bioengineers because of their potential to allow the targeted delivery of drugs, proteins, and mRNAs to specific cells of interest.<ref name="Corchero 2011">{{cite journal|last1=Corchero|first1=José L|last2=Cedano|first2=Juan|title=Self-assembling, protein-based intracellular bacterial organelles: emerging vehicles for encapsulating, targeting and delivering therapeutical cargoes|journal=Microbial Cell Factories|date=2011|volume=10|issue=1|pages=92|doi=10.1186/1475-2859-10-92}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Moon|first1=H|last2=Lee|first2=J|last3=Kim|first3=H|last4=Heo|first4=S|last5=Min|first5=J|last6=Kang|first6=S|title=Genetically engineering encapsulin protein cage nanoparticle as a SCC-7 cell targeting optical nanoprobe.|journal=Biomaterials research|date=2014|volume=18|pages=21|doi=10.1186/2055-7124-18-21|pmid=26331071|pmc=4552281}}</ref><ref name="Tamura 2015">{{cite journal|last1=Tamura|first1=A|last2=Fukutani|first2=Y|last3=Takami|first3=T|last4=Fujii|first4=M|last5=Nakaguchi|first5=Y|last6=Murakami|first6=Y|last7=Noguchi|first7=K|last8=Yohda|first8=M|last9=Odaka|first9=M|title=Packaging guest proteins into the encapsulin nanocompartment from Rhodococcus erythropolis N771.|journal=Biotechnology and Bioengineering|date=January 2015|volume=112|issue=1|pages=13–20|doi=10.1002/bit.25322|pmid=24981030}}</ref>

{{Infobox organisation | image = EURORDIS.svg | size = 200px | leader_title = President | leader_name = Yann Le Cam | established = 1997 }}
The '''European Organisation for Rare Diseases''' ('''EURORDIS''') is a non-governmental patient-driven alliance of patient organizations and individuals active in the field of rare diseases, that promotes research on [[rare disease]]s and commercial development of [[orphan drug]]s. EURORDIS is a dedicated to improving the quality of life of all people living with rare diseases in Europe. It was founded in 1997; it is supported by its members and by the French Muscular Dystrophy Association (AFM), the European Commission, corporate foundations and the health industry.<ref name="eurordis.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurordis.org/content/brief-0|title=EURORDIS in brief|website=www.eurordis.org}}</ref>
There are an estimated 20–30 million people living with rare diseases in Europe alone,<ref name="pmid15553406"/> and an estimated 6,000 rare diseases. EURORDIS represents more than 700 rare disease organizations in 63 different countries (of which 26 are EU Member States), covering more than 2,000 rare diseases.<ref name="eurordis.org"/>
EURORDIS is a development of the patient self-advocacy movement, itself widely attributed to [[AIDS activism]].<ref name="pmid15069992">{{cite journal | author = Houyez F | title = Active involvement of patients in drug research, evaluation, and commercialization: European perspective | journal = J Ambul Care Manage | volume = 27 | issue = 2 | pages = 139–45 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15069992 | doi = | url = http://meta.wkhealth.com/pt/pt-core/template-journal/lwwgateway/media/landingpage.htm?issn=0148-9917&volume=27&issue=2&spage=139 | issn = }}</ref>
EURORDIS was the founding partner of [[Rare Disease Day]] in 2008 and remains its lead coordinator.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rarediseaseday.org|title=Rare Disease Day 2018 - 28 Feb|website=Rare Disease Day - 28 Feb 2018}}</ref>
National organizations with a similar focus include [[National Organization for Rare Disorders]] (NORD) in the [[United States]], [[Canadian Organization for Rare Disorders]] (CORD) in [[Canada]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.raredisorders.ca|title=Canadian Organization for Rare Disorders|website=www.raredisorders.ca}}</ref> Allianz Chronischer Seltener Erkrankungen (ACHSE) in Germany, and Federación Española de Enfermedades Raras (FEDER) in [[Spain]].<ref name="pmid15553406">{{cite journal | author = Nogales Espert A | title = [Rare diseases: a new chapter in medicine] | language = Spanish| journal = An R Acad Nac Med (Madr) | volume = 121 | issue = 1 | pages = 139–51; discussion 151–5 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15553406 | doi = | url = | issn = }}</ref>

{{Infobox journal | title = Gender, Work & Organization | cover = | editor =Deborah Kerfoot, Ida Sabelis and Alison Pullen | discipline = [[Women's Studies]] | former_names = | abbreviation = Gend. Work Organ. | publisher = [[John Wiley & Sons]] | country = | frequency = Bimonthly | history = 1994-present | openaccess = [[Hybrid open access journal|Hybrid]] | license = | impact = 1.548 | impact-year = 2016 | website = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1468-0432 | link1 = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1468-0432/currentissue | link1-name = Online access | link2 = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1468-0432/issues | link2-name = Online archive | JSTOR = | OCLC = 37447061 | LCCN = sn94030770 | CODEN = GWORF8 | ISSN = 0968-6673 | eISSN = 1468-0432 }} '''''Gender, Work & Organization''''' is a bimonthly [[peer-reviewed]] [[academic journal]]. The journal was established in 1994 and is published by [[John Wiley & Sons]]. It covers research on the role of gender on the workfloor. The [[editors-in-chief]] are Deborah Kerfoot ([[Keele University]]), Ida Sabelis ([[Vrije Universiteit]]) and Alison Pullen ([[Macquarie University]]). In addition to the regular issues, the journal publishes several special issues per year.
== Abstracting and indexing == The journal is abstracted and indexed in: {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[ABI/INFORM]] * [[EBSCO Publishing|EBSCO databases]] * [[ProQuest|ProQuest databases]] * [[Current Contents]]/Social & Behavioral Sciences<ref name=ISI>{{cite web |url=http://ip-science.thomsonreuters.com/mjl/ |title=Master Journal List |publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] |work=Intellectual Property & Science |accessdate=2015-04-02}}</ref> * [[Emerald Management Reviews]] * [[Educational Research Abstracts Online]] * [[GEOBASE]]<ref name=GEOBASE>{{cite web |url=http://www.elsevier.com/online-tools/engineering-village/contentdatabase-overview |title=Content/Database Overview - GEOBASE Source List|publisher=[[Elsevier]] |work=Engineering Village |accessdate=2015-04-02}}</ref> * [[International Bibliography of the Social Sciences]] * [[PsycINFO]]/[[Psychological Abstracts]] * [[Scopus]]<ref name=Scopus>{{cite web |url=http://www.elsevier.com/online-tools/scopus/content-overview |title=Content overview |publisher=[[Elsevier]] |work=Scopus |accessdate=2015-04-02}}</ref> * [[Social Sciences Citation Index]]<ref name=ISI/> * [[Studies on Women and Gender Abstracts]] }} According to the ''[[Journal Citation Reports]]'', the journal has a 2015 [[impact factor]] of 1.325, ranking it 10th out of 40 journals in the category "Women's Studies" and 93rd out of 192 in the category "Management".<ref name=WoS>{{cite book |year=2016 |chapter=Journals Ranked by Impact: Women's Studies and Management |title=2015 [[Journal Citation Reports]] |publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] |edition=Social Sciences |series=[[Web of Science]]}}</ref>

[[File:Hamlin's Wizard Oil poster.jpg|right|thumb|upright|Advertising poster from about 1890]]
'''Hamlin's Wizard Oil''' was an American [[patent medicine]] sold as a [[cure-all]] under the slogan "There is no Sore it will Not Heal, No Pain it will not Subdue."
==History== First produced in 1861 in Chicago<ref name=elgin>{{cite web|url=http://www.elginhistory.com/dgb/ch07.htm|title=Chapter 7: Good Old Days|last=Alft|first=E. C.|work=Elgin: Days Gone By|publisher=Elgin History|accessdate=2009-09-25}}</ref> by former magician John Austen Hamlin and his brother Lysander Butler Hamlin, it was primarily sold and used as a [[liniment]] for [[Rheumatism|rheumatic pain]] and sore muscles, but was advertised as a treatment for pneumonia, cancer, diphtheria, earache, toothache, headache and [[rabies|hydrophobia]].<ref name=elgin/><ref name=herb/> It was made of 50%-70% alcohol containing [[camphor]], [[ammonia]], [[chloroform]], [[sassafras]], [[cloves]], and [[turpentine]], and was said to be usable both internally and topically.<ref name=herb>{{cite web|url=http://www.herbcompanion.com/Health/PATENT-medicines.aspx?page=3|title=Patent Medicines|last=Long|first=Jim|date=February–March 1993|work=Herb Companion|accessdate=2009-09-25}}</ref>
Traveling performance troupes advertised the product in [[medicine show]]s across the Midwest,<ref>{{cite book|last=Anderson|first=Ann|title=Snake oil, hustlers and hambones: the American medicine show|publisher=McFarland & Company|year=2000|pages=190|isbn=0-7864-0800-6}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=McNamara|first=Brooks|title=Step right up |publisher=University Press of Mississippi|year=1995|pages=249|isbn=0-87805-831-1}}</ref> with runs as long as six weeks in a town. They used horse-drawn wagons and dressed in silk top hats, [[frock coat]]s, pinstriped trousers, and patent leather shoes—with [[Spats (footwear)|spats]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.quackwatch.com/13Hx/TM/12.html|title=Chapter 12: Medicine Show|last=Young|first=James Harvey|year=1961|work=The Toadstool Millionaires: A Social History of Patent Medicines in America before Federal Regulation|publisher=Princeton University Press|accessdate=2009-09-25}}</ref> They distributed song books at the shows and in [[druggist]]s.<ref>{{cite book|last=Strasser|first=Susan|title=Public culture: diversity, democracy, and community in the United States|editor=Marguerite S. Shaffer|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|year=2008|pages=376|chapter=Sponsorship and Snake Oil: Medicine Shows and Contemporary Public Culture|isbn=0-8122-4081-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k8G7gftI87cC&pg=PA95&lpg=PA95#v=onepage&q=&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Humorous and sentimental songs as sung throughout the United States by Hamlin's Wizard Oil Concert Troupes in their open air advertising concerts|publisher=Hamlin's Wizard Oil Co.|series=CIHM/ICMH Microfiche series, no. 50670.|pages=33|isbn=0-665-50670-8|oclc=855363136}}</ref> Performers included [[James Whitcomb Riley]], singer and composer [[Paul Dresser]] from Indiana,<ref>{{cite web|last=Henderson|first=Clayton W|title=Paul Dresser|publisher = [[Indiana Historical Society]]|url =http://www.indianahistory.org/our-collections/library-and-archives/notable-hoosiers/paul-dresser|accessdate=2012-10-12}}</ref> and [[southern gospel|southern gospel music]] progenitor [[Charles Davis Tillman]].
At these gatherings John Austen Hamlin delivered lectures replete with humor borrowed from the writings of [[Robert Jones Burdette]].<ref>{{cite book |last = Carson |first = Gerald |title = One for a man, two for a horse: A pictorial history, grave and comic, of patent medicines |location = Garden City, New York |publisher = Doubleday |year = 1961 |page = 37 }}</ref>
[[Grinnell College]] research points out that the Hamlins claimed efficacy for Wizard Oil on not only human beings but also horses and cattle, one poster displaying an elephant drinking the stuff by lifting the bottle with the trunk. Bottles came in 35¢ and 75¢ sizes.<ref>[http://web.grinnell.edu/courses/sst/f01/sst395-01/PublicPages/PerfectDrugs/Kendra/USMedicineShows/HamlinWizardOil/index.html Grinnell College site "Perfect Drugs" on "Hamlin's Wizard Oil Company"] ("Before the FDA: Quack Cures to Medicine Shows"). ''Cf''. the [http://www.csufresno.edu/folklore/ballads/San052.html CSU Fresno site] by Robert B. Waltz.</ref> [[Carl Sandburg]] inserted two versions of lyrics titled "Wizard Oil" together with a tune into his ''American Songbag'' (1927).<ref>Carl Sandburg, ''The American Songbag'' (San Diego: Harcourt Brace, 1927), pp. 52-54. Sandburg indicated that his selections were arranged by Henry Francis Parks on the basis of recollections by Harry E. Randall as communicated to Neeta Marquis. The likelihood is that Sandburg added some of his own influence.</ref>
In 1916, Lysander's son Lawrence B. Hamlin of [[Elgin, Illinois|Elgin]], by then manager of the firm, was fined $200 under the 1906 [[Pure Food and Drug Act]] for advertising that Hamlin's Wizard Oil could "check the growth and permanently kill cancer."<ref name=elgin/>
==See also== * [[List of topics characterized as pseudoscience]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.hamlinswizardoil.com/index.php Website tribute to Hamlin's Wizard Oil] *[https://www.nlm.nih.gov/exhibition/ephemera/medshow.html Here Today, Here Tomorrow... Varieties of Medical Ephemera from the US National Library of Medicine]
